questions.question_text:
A cybersecurity analyst has several SIEM event logs to review for possible APT activity. The analyst was given several items that include lists of indicators for both
IP addresses and domains. Which of the following actions is the BEST approach for the analyst to perform?

choices.D: Scan for vulnerabilities with exploits known to have been used by an APT.
choices.B: Analyze the trends of the events while manually reviewing to see if any of the indicators match.
choices.C: Create an advanced query that includes all of the indicators, and review any of the matches.
choices.A: Use the IP addresses to search through the event logs.

discussion.content:
I ran across this exact question in Udemy (Really good site. Gotta pay but the have tons of videos and test prep stuff) and the answer is B. Here's their explanation:
 Explanation
"While all of the answers could provide some insight into the APT’s actions, only “Analyze the trends of the events while manually reviewing them to see if any indicators match” effectively will answer this question. If you only use the IP addresses to search the event logs, you would miss any events that correlated only to the domain names. If you create an advanced query with ALL of the indicators, your search of the event logs will find nothing, because no single event will include ALL of these IPs and domain names. Finally, while scanning for vulnerabilities known to have been used by the APTs is a good practice, it would only be effective in determining how to stop future attacks from occurring, not for piecing together whether or not an attack has already occurred."

comments.content: This doesn't make a lot of sense to me. An advanced query would be something that consists of "or" statements. You'd be search for events where source/destination ip addresses are X or Y or Z. Same for domain names.

discussion.content: This question was in the exam :)

Should be C. Not sure how you identify intrusion in your SOCs, but it should be definitely matching for IOCs from Threat Intel reports on your network.

Not B, APTs are stealthy, this is Behavioral Analysis(sudden spike) but if the attack is stealthy you will not pick it up.
Not D, this is not the tools/approach provided. You are provided with a SIEM and IPs and Domains IOCs for finding the APTs.

Def B, An APT may have been on the network for a long time. Trend analysis will show you any strange behaviour over time.
Similar Q in 002

This is B indeed. 

You should begin by analyzing the trends of the events while manually reviewing each of them to determine if any of the indicators match. If you only searched through the event logs using the IP addresses, this would not be sufficient as many APTs hide their activity by compromising and using legitimate networks and their IP addresses. If you only use the IP addresses to search the event logs, you would miss any events that correlated only to the domain names. If you create an advanced query will all of the indicators, your search of the event logs will find nothing because no single event will include all of these IPs and domain names. Finally, while scanning for vulnerabilities known to have been used by the APTs is a good practice, it would only be effective in determining how to stop future attacks from occurring, not for determining whether or not an attack has already occurred.

comments.content: why did you copy the exact same thing TT said. could this be a sabotage?

discussion.content: should be C: APT detection via behavioral analysis of the SIEM aggregated log files
i think big willy
I think its C because this is one of the functions from a SIEM. I cant believe that someone not use the query und work manually

comments.content: Logically, “several” doesn’t specify whether it’s many or few.

discussion.content: The analyst was given SEVERAL events... not many.
you might be manually reviewing thousands of entries. I think it really should be c
Is this really B? Or can be C?
